item.title: Taiwan Dollar Hits Three-Year High on Fund Inflows, Repatriation
item.description: Taiwan’s dollar rallied to its strongest in three years amid inflows to its stock market and broad-based weakness in the greenback.
item.dc:creator: Betty Hou

item.title: Shifting Rate Bets Push Dollar, Bond Yields Lower: Markets Wrap
item.description: The dollar declined and Treasury yields edged lower on bets that US rate cuts could come sooner than expected, after a report that President Donald Trump is considering an early appointment for the next Federal Reserve chairman.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Thomas

media:content.media:description: Buildings in Pudong's Lujiazui Financial District in Shanghai, China, on Monday, March 3, 2025. President Xi Jinping heads into China's biggest political huddle of the year with his economy finally getting back some swagger. Photographer: Raul Ariano/Bloomberg

item.title: The Market Is Getting Back to Ignoring Iran
item.description: But it’s too soon to Make America Exceptional Again.
item.dc:creator: John Authers

media:content.media:description: On the beach in Tel Aviv.

item.title: Greenland Miner Eyes US, EU Deals After Trump Boosted Interest
item.description: Greenland’s biggest miner Amaroq Minerals Ltd is in talks with several state-backed agencies as Donald Trump’s political spotlight translates into concrete investor interest, the company’s chief executive officer said.
item.dc:creator: Sanne Wass

media:content.media:description: Amaroq CEO Eldur Olafsson following the company’s first gold pour in Greenland in November 2024. Source: Amaroq

item.title: Guotai Junan Surges 300% This Week on Crypto-Trading Approval
item.description: Guotai Junan International Holdings Ltd. shares are headed for their best week on record after the broker obtained regulatory approval to offer trading services of cryptocurrencies in Hong Kong.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Zhu, Jing Jin

item.title: Gold Edges Higher With Middle East Truce, Fed Rate Path in Focus
item.description: Gold edged higher as the dollar dipped and investors watched for clearer signs that Israel-Iran tensions won’t spill over into war again, and for more certainty on the Federal Reserve’s rate path.
item.dc:creator: Yihui Xie

item.title: Hong Kong Intervenes to Defend FX Peg as Local Currency Drops
item.description: Hong Kong’s de-facto central bank spent more than a billion dollars propping up the city’s exchange rate, as it sought to defend a currency peg that has been strained by volatility in the greenback.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Zhu, Wenjin Lv

item.title: Hong Kong May Need Further FX Intervention, OCBC Bank Says
item.description: OCBC Bank's Frances Cheung shares her views on the Hong Kong dollar (HKD) after the city's monetary authority intervened to defend the peg to the US dollar (USD). She tells Bloomberg Television that the amount of local currency the HKMA bought "was actually quite small" and that she suspects "further or additional FX intervention will be needed." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Oil Holds Gain as Trump Maintains Iran Pressure, Stockpiles Fall
item.description: Oil held a gain after US President Donald Trump said his maximum pressure campaign on Iranian oil will continue, and a government report showed another large decline in American crude stockpiles.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Chen

item.title: Tokyo Gas Said in Talks to Seal Long-Term US LNG Purchase Deals
item.description: Tokyo Gas is in discussion with multiple US liquefied natural gas suppliers to secure a long-term purchase agreement, as rising energy demand leaves Japan increasingly dependent on the fuel source.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Liao, Stephen Stapczynski

media:content.media:description: Tokyo Gas storage tanks for natural gas in Tokyo, Japan.

item.title: Last Qantas Bear Finally Surrenders After Stock Dips From Record
item.description: The sole bearish Qantas Airways Ltd. analyst has finally yielded, giving Chief Executive Officer Vanessa Hudson unanimous support from the market as she pushes through the biggest fleet overhaul in the Australian airline’s 105-year history.
item.dc:creator: Angus Whitley

item.title: Indian Tech Stocks Rally Has Legs As Earnings Outlook Improves
item.description: Before the trading day starts we bring you a digest of the key news and events that are likely to move markets. Today we look at:
item.dc:creator: Ashutosh Joshi

item.title: China Opens First Offshore Gold Vault in Hong Kong
item.description: The Shanghai Gold Exchange has expanded outside mainland China for the first time, with the roll out of two new contracts and a bullion vault in Hong Kong.
item.dc:creator: Yihui Xie, Sybilla Gross

item.title: Copper Extends Gains as Goldman Sees 2025 Price Peak in August
item.description: Copper extended gains for a fifth day, after Goldman Sachs Group Inc. said it expected prices to rise to a 2025 peak of around $10,050 a ton in August, as supplies outside the US tighten.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Zhu, Winnie Zhu

media:content.media:description: Copper rods at a wholesale metal dealer in Mumbai, India.

item.title: JC Flowers-Backed Jefferson Capital’s IPO Raises $150 Million
item.description: Jefferson Capital Inc. and some of its backers raised $150 million in an initial public offering, pricing shares at the bottom of the range.
item.dc:creator: Georgie McKay, Anthony Hughes

media:content.media:description: The Nasdaq MarketSite in New York, US, on Tuesday, April 22, 2025. US stocks pared gains as traders weighed earlier remarks from Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent on the US-China tariff standoff. Photographer: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg

item.title: Richard Li’s FWD Group Seeks $442 Million in Hong Kong IPO
item.description: Billionaire Richard Li’s FWD Group Holdings Ltd. is seeking to raise HK$3.5 billion ($442 million) in a Hong Kong initial public offering, seizing on a hot market to finally launch a share sale initially planned four years ago.
item.dc:creator: Julia Fioretti

media:content.media:description: Signage for FWD Group Holdings Ltd. atop a building in Hong Kong, China, on Friday, Aug. 2, 2024. Hong Kong is seeing an influx of professionals from mainland China’s finance and tech sectors who are disillusioned with their career and salary prospects across the border. Many are trying to make a living and stay in the city by peddling insurance products, giving a boost to a once-sleepy industry.

item.title: AT&T Finds Efficiencies in Fiber Push
item.description: AT&T has begun to decommission its legacy copper networks, with the intention of completely retiring them by the end of the decade. On Bloomberg Chief Future Officer, CFO Pascal Desroches takes Lisa Abramowicz to one of the company's connectivity hubs and explains how fiber isn't just less costly to operate and maintain -- it also takes up less space, allowing AT&T to generate capital from underutilized facilities. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: How AT&T Found Its Focus
item.description: Since John Stankey became AT&T CEO in 2020, the company has streamlined its focus around connectivity and concentrated on developing fiber broadband and 5G wireless networks. On Bloomberg Chief Future Office, Stankey and CFO Pascal Desroches tell Lisa Abramowicz why they're confident that AT&T is positioned to turn this technological foundation into profitable growth. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Chief Future Officer: Pascal Desroches, AT&T
item.description: Chief Financial Officers now play a critical role in shaping corporate strategy and positioning organizations to meet future challenges. This episode profiles AT&T CFO Pascal Desroches, who has partnered with CEO John Stankey to restructure the company around a core of fiber and 5G wireless connectivity. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Foreign Investors Sold Japan Stocks for First Time in 12 Weeks
item.description: Foreign investors were net sellers of Japanese stocks last week for the first time since March, according to data from the Ministry of Finance.
item.dc:creator: Hideyuki Sano, Momoka Yokoyama

item.title: Kingsoft Cloud CFO on China AI Trends
item.description: Henry He, CFO at Kingsoft Cloud, discusses the trends and opportunities with AI in China. He speaks with Bloomberg’s Stephen Engle on the sidelines of the World Economic Forum in Tianjin. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: UBS Fang on China Market Outlook
item.description: Tommie Fang, Head of China Global Markets at UBS, discusses his outlook and strategies for global investors for the Chinese market. He speaks with Stephen Engle on the sidelines at the World Economic Forum’s Annual Meeting of the New Champions in Tianjin on "Bloomberg: The Asia Trade". (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: DHL Executive on Tariff Impact
item.description: A DHL executive says global trade has shown surprising resilience despite uncertainties caused by President Trump's tariffs. Aditi Rasquinha, Greater China CEO of the logistics giant's forwarding arm spoke to Bloomberg at the World Economic Forum event in Tianjin. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: China's Manycore Tech Unfazed by US Chip Curbs
item.description: Chinese spatial design software maker Manycore Tech says its business model isn't affected by US restrictions on chip exports. Co-founder and Chairman Victor Huang spoke with Bloomberg about how he's managing the global growth of the firm that is part of a group referred to as "China's six little dragons", that includes Deepseek. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Indonesia’s Yield Curve May Steepen as BI Unwinds Intervention
item.description: Indonesia’s sovereign yield curve is set to steepen as the central bank reduces its use of short-term rupiah securities, prompting a shift in demand toward government bonds.
item.dc:creator: Marcus Wong

item.title: Mars’ $36 Billion Kellanova Deal Hit by Full-Scale EU Probe
item.description: Mars Inc.’s $36 billion bid for Pringles chips maker Kellanova faces a potential glitch after European Union opened an in-depth investigation over concerns the largest packaged-food deal in almost a decade could thwart competition.
item.dc:creator: Samuel Stolton

media:content.media:description: Packages of Pringles chips, manufactured by Kellanova.

item.title: AIIB President Jin on Tariff Risks, Membership
item.description: AIIB President, Jin Liqun says free trade remains the strongest defense against rising tariffs. In an exclusive interview in Beijing, Jin also signaled openness to working with non-member countries—including the United States. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: EU Strikes Deal on Failed-Lenders Rules
item.description: The European Union agreed on rules to ease winding down smaller lenders in trouble, part of an effort to bring closer banking sectors of its member states.
item.dc:creator: Lyubov Pronina

media:content.media:description: European Union (EU) flags fly near the Europa building in Brussels, Belgium, on Tuesday, Feb. 9, 2021. Ukraine is working to introduce more transparent regulation in the natural gas industry, where it also wants to strengthen links with the European Union. Photographer: Geert Vanden Wijngaert/Bloomberg

item.title: Principles of Success With Bill Belichick and Ray Dalio
item.description: Alex Rodriguez and Jason Kelly sit for a special conversation with two titans, football coach Bill Belichick and Bridgewater founder Ray Dalio, to learn their guiding principles for success. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: China’s Xiaomi to Launch First SUV as Shares Near Record High
item.description: The unveiling of Xiaomi Corp.’s first electric SUV on Thursday will showcase how the Chinese tech company has become an investor darling with its high-stakes bet on the auto market.
item.dc:creator: Charlotte Yang

media:content.media:description: Xiaomi YU7 Photographer: CFOTO/Future Publishing/Getty Images
